resources.string: Measurement
Data On Weighing
Hello World from section: %1$d
Density Tower
Egg Float
Sinkers And Floaters
Cartesian Diver
Construction of a Eureka Can
Student As Matter

Fix a rubber band at one end to a table or retort stand. At the other end, attach a paper clip to act as a pointer and a small bag or scale pan. Fill the bag or scale pan with successive numbers of nails. Have students measure the extension of the rubber band each time they add more nails. Record the readings and use the data to draw a graph as shown in the ﬁgure.
Syringes, water, honey, glycerine, cooking oil, spirit, kerosene, small objects

Add each liquid into the syringe, one by one, observing the relative depths of each liquid. Place small solid objects e.g. rubber erasers, paper clips, small nails, etc. into the syringe and observe their positions relative to the various liquids.
Which liquid is the most dense? Which is the least dense?
The denser liquids sink to the bottom while the less dense liquids rise to the top. The solid objects settle among liquids of comparable density.
Relative densities of liquids and solids help to identify certain substances, e.g. whether a ring is really made of gold.
Food coloring can be added to colorless liquids such as water, kerosene and glycerine to help distinguish among them.
2 fresh eggs, 2 containers (bottles cut in half), salt (less than half a cup)
Fill the two containers with water and place a fresh egg in each.
Leave one as it is and add salt to the other. Add and mix salt until the egg ﬂoats in the saltwater container.
Why does the egg ﬂoat in saltwater but sink in fresh water?

Saltwater has a greater density than fresh water. A fresh egg has a density between fresh water and saltwater. Since an egg is denser than freshwater, it sinks. Since an egg is less dense than saltwater, it ﬂoats.
This is the same reason why it is easier to stay aﬂoat when swimming in the ocean (saltwater) as opposed to a lake (fresh water).
Basin of water, various objects, e.g. nail, paper clip, paper, aluminum foil, soda cap, matchbox, pen cap, toothpick, balloons, ﬂour
Fill one balloon with ﬂour, one with water, and one with air. They should all be the same size.
Have students predict the outcome for each object. Then place each object in the water, ﬁrst by placing very carefully, then by dropping it in.
1. What factors aﬀect whether an object sinks or ﬂoats? \n2. How do large objects such as boats ﬂoat?

A bottle cap placed carefully on the surface of the water will ﬂoat, but when pushed under, will sink. A sheet of aluminum foil will ﬂoat while a sheet of the same size which is folded several times will sink. A balloon ﬁlled with ﬂour sinks, one ﬁlled with water just ﬂoats, and one ﬁlled with air ﬂoats above the surface.

Flotation depends on buoyancy. If the buoyancy force on an object (upward force from ﬂuid) is greater than its weight (downward force from gravity), the object will ﬂoat. However if the weight is greater than the buoyancy, the object will sink. The weight of an object depends on its average density, so decreasing average density (by ﬁlling it with air, for example) can allow even very heavy objects, such as steel boats, to ﬂoat.
Conduct this activity as an experiment with students. Let them make predictions on which items will sink and ﬂoat beforehand.
1.5 L plastic bottle, balloon, paper clips (large), water

Fill the bottle with water. Fix a large paper clip to the lip of a balloon. Making sure to keep all air out of the balloon, insert it into the bottle. It should just ﬂoat at the top while remaining completely submerged. Adjust depending on type of balloon and paper clips.
Screw the cap on the bottle and squeeze the middle of the bottle, then release.
The balloon should begin to sink when you squeeze, but ﬂoat again when you release.

While water is nearly incompressible, the balloon (and any small amount of air inside) is compressible. This means when you squeeze the bottle, the water remains unchanged, but the balloon is compressed, decreasing its volume and so increasing its density. Before squeezing, it was less dense than the water and so it ﬂoated. After squeezing, it becomes denser than the water and sinks.
Plastic bottle, knife
Cut a plastic bottle about 10 cm from the bottom. Cut 2 slits at the top of the bottle and bend the strip forward to form a spout.
Measuring the volume of irregular objects, Archimedes’ Principle
Use students to demonstrate the concept of states of matter.

When students or objects are close together, they represent particles in the solid state. As they move apart and past each other they represent particles in the liquid state. Fast and randomly moving pupils or objects represent particles in the gaseous state.
Bottle caps, paper
Have students arrange bottle caps to represent the different states of matter, using labels from paper or cardboard.
The spacing of the bottle caps represents the distance between particles in each state. Particles have large spaces between them in gases, less space in liquids, and are very condensed in solids.
Tin can, glass bottle, water, Heat Sources
Pour a small amount of water into a tin can and heat it until it boils. Fill a bottle with cool water and hold it above the tin can.
Water drops form on the outside of the cool bottle when it is touched by the steam of the boiling water.
Water particles escape from the boiling water as vapour and condense on the lower surface of the bottle to form water droplets. Hence water is made up of small particles.
2 large and 2 small plastic bags, water, 2 large seeds/stones, small seeds/coloured paper, grass, cardboard box
Make models of plant and animal cells as shown.
2 glass sheets, match, rubber bands, water, food colour (optional)
With the help of a rubber band and a matchstick, arrange two clean glass sheets as shown in the diagram. Place the arrangement in a plate containing some water.
Water rises to different heights along and between the glass sheets.

This is capillary action. Capillary rise results from adhesion, allowing the liquid to climb along the surface of the glass, as well as cohesion, which pulls the remainder of the liquid up. Water rises more where the glass sheets are closer together.
Matches, water, straw, plastic lid

Break several matches near the middle, but not so that they come apart. They should make acute angles. Place them on the plastic lid and place a few drops of water on the broken joints of the matches using the straw.
The matches close and return to their original straight shape.
Water gets absorbed in the wooden matchstick and causes it to expand.
This is why it is difficult to open a wooden door after it rains. The water rises up the wood causing it to expand into its frame.
Paper, chalk, small dish/lid, water, food colour
Cut oﬀ the bottom of a plastic bottle to make a water dish.
Place a strip of paper and a piece of chalk in a dish containing water. Leave the objects for some time and measure the rise in colour of each using a ruler.
The water rises faster in the chalk than in the paper.
Chalk has smaller capillaries than paper, which allows water to rise faster.
Capillary action can be used to provide automatic irrigation for plants. Students can perform irrigation by dipping a porous material such as paper or cotton cloth in water.
Cards of hazard symbols
Play a game with the symbol charts. A student is given a hazard symbol. He has to explain the hazard shown and to explain the necessary safety precautions in order to avoid that hazard.
Arranging States of Matter
Changes of State
Cell Models
Capillary Rise
Moving Matches
Measuring Capillary Rise
Automatic Irrigation
A Safety Game
Flower Structure
Seed Germination
Condition For Germination
Card or plastic, sticks, stones paper, clay or Plasticine
Make the major parts of a ﬂower from card or plastic, sticks and clay. Petals can be made from paper.
Look at a variety of ﬂowers, fruit and seeds from the local environment.
Seeds or beans, small bottles, water, avocado pits

Cut plastic bottles to make containers. In the ﬁrst, add soil with beans and water every day. In the second, ﬁll mostly with water and place an avocado seed inside. In the third, ﬁll mostly with water and place a potato inside.
The stages of germination can be seen over time.
The avocado and potato undergo hydroponic germination, since the seed is sprouted by water, air and sunlight only.
4 bottles or syringes, cotton wool, beans or seeds, water, oil

Place cotton wool at the bottom of each container and add a few beans or seeds to each. In container 1, add enough water to soak the cotton wool. In 2, add cool boiled water to ﬂood the seeds and a small amount of oil. In 3, add ice water. In 4, do not add any water. Record observations over several days.
Only container 1 will show proper germination. The others will show little or no growth because they do not have the conditions necessary for germination.
Plastic bottle, balloons, plastic bag, string/rubber band, straw

Cut the bottom oﬀ a plastic bottle. Attach a balloon over the bottle mouth so it hangs inside. Fix a piece of plastic bag over the cut base end using string or a rubber band. (Optional: Fix a straw through the bottle top and attach 1 or 2 balloons to the end inside the bottle.)
Pulling the plastic bag down causes the balloon to inflate; pushing it up causes the balloon the deﬂate.

The balloon(s) represents the lung(s), the plastic bag the diaphragm, the bottle the thoracic cavity (and the straw the esophagus). Pulling the plastic sheet down causes an expansion of the cavity bringing about inspiration and causing the balloon to inflate. Pushing the sheet up reduces the volume of the cavity, causing expiration and the balloon to deﬂate.
Tell students that this model does not show the expansion and contraction of the rib cage with breathing.
Cards
Cut out cards to represent the substances involved in respiration. Label some cards with a ‘+’ or an arrow. Mix up the cards and ask students to arrange them correctly as shown.
Various seeds, bottle caps, coins, etc., plates, card

Choose 3 different types of seed, coin or bottle cap to represent carbon, hydrogen and oxygen. Arrange 4 plates or boxes on a table as shown. Ask students to place the correct number of seeds etc. on the plates. When the seeds are placed correctly the card carrying the ‘E’ for energy is added.
Demonstrate that the reverse equation is the process of photosynthesis.
Large plastic bag, bucket, water, basin

Fill the bucket to the brim with water and stand it in the basin. Blow into an empty plastic bag or balloon. Submerge the bag in the bucket. Collect the overﬂowing water and measure the volume. Do this for regular breaths, deep breaths and breaths after holding for 10 seconds.
A regular breath may be around 0.5 L, while a full breath can exceed 3 L.
Stiff cardboard, scissors, nails, string, water, basin
Construct the water wheel as shown.
Tie a small weight (e.g. paperclip, nail) to the string so that it rests on the ﬂoor. Pour water over the water wheel to turn it and lift the weight.

Water stores potential energy in the forms of rivers and waterfalls and when placed in an elevated storage tank. The kinetic energy of falling water can be used to do work on an object and generate electricity.
Paper/thin cardstock, scissors, pen, glue, paper fastener/thumb tack, straw or stick, colored pencils (optional)

Copy the illustration onto a sheet of paper or thin cardstock. Cut along the lines and make holes with a pen. Bend the four corners together into the center and glue them in place. Push the fastener through the center into a straw or stick.
Wind provides kinetic energy which can be harnessed with a device such as a windmill and used to generate electricity if connected to a turbine.
Three clothespins, scissors
Tie the handles of a spring clothespin together with one loop of string. Place it in between two other clothespins on a ﬂat table as shown. Cut or burn the string.
The two clothespins on either side ﬂy oﬀ in opposite directions.
The spring in the clothespin stores potential energy which is released when the string is cut. This energy is converted into kinetic energy, seen by the movement of the other clothespins.
Copper (II) sulphate, zinc metal (from dry cell), copper wire, steel wool, ammeter/bulb
Prepare a 2 M solution of copper (II) sulphate and clean pieces of copper wire and zinc using steel wool.
Connect the zinc anode, ammeter/bulb and copper cathode in series using connecting wires. Dip the zinc and copper electrodes into the copper (II) sulphate solution. Read the current on the ammeter.
The ammeter shows a deflection, possibly around 0.05 A.
The current produced indicates that the chemical energy inherent in the electrodes and the electrolyte solution is converted to electrical energy.
Breathing Model
Respiration Cards
Respiration Plates
Lung Capacity
